title: Week 1
desc: Pregnancy is counted from the first day of your last period; biologically you aren’t yet pregnant but your body is preparing for ovulation.
babyDevelopment: No embryo yet — the body is preparing for ovulation and potential fertilization.
nutrition: Start folic acid (400–800 mcg daily) if planning pregnancy; eat leafy greens, beans, and whole grains.

title: Week 2
desc: Ovulation typically happens this week; if sperm meets egg, fertilization may follow.
babyDevelopment: Still preconception; the egg is released and awaits fertilization.
nutrition: Continue prenatal vitamins, hydrate, include protein-rich local foods like beans and eggs.

title: Week 3
desc: Fertilization typically occurs and the zygote begins dividing as it travels to the uterus.
babyDevelopment: A fertilized egg (zygote) becomes a blastocyst as cells divide and prepare for implantation.
nutrition: Avoid alcohol and tobacco; emphasize folate, B vitamins and lean protein.

title: Week 4
desc: Implantation occurs and early pregnancy hormones (hCG) rise; a pregnancy test may become positive.
babyDevelopment: The blastocyst attaches to the uterine lining and the placenta begins to form.
nutrition: Keep taking folic acid and iron; eat vitamin C–rich fruits to improve iron absorption (oranges, pawpaw).

title: Week 5
desc: The embryo is forming rapidly; early symptoms like fatigue and nausea may appear.
babyDevelopment: Neural tube begins to form; primitive heart begins to beat.
nutrition: Continue folate-rich foods (kontomire/leafy greens), lean protein, and small frequent meals if nauseous.

title: Week 6
desc: Embryo growth accelerates — facial features begin to form and limb buds appear.
babyDevelopment: Arm and leg buds form; rudimentary eyes and ears begin to develop; heartbeat detectable in some scans.
nutrition: Ginger for nausea (tea), whole grains for energy, and iron-rich snacks like groundnuts and beans.

title: Week 7
desc: Organ systems continue to form; early pregnancy symptoms may persist.
babyDevelopment: Major organs are forming; brain development continues rapidly.
nutrition: Ensure adequate fluids and iron; include vitamin-B rich foods and protein (fish low in mercury, eggs).

title: Week 8
desc: Embryo is more recognizable and moving but movements aren’t felt yet.
babyDevelopment: Fingers and toes begin separating; facial features refine further.
nutrition: Continue prenatal vitamins and calcium-rich foods (milk, small fish with bones), and eat fiber to ease constipation.

title: Week 9
desc: The embryo is now called a fetus and continues developing organs and structures.
babyDevelopment: Muscles and nerves begin working together; facial features and limbs become more defined.
nutrition: Prioritize iron and vitamin C to aid absorption — e.g., kontomire stew and oranges; stay hydrated.

title: Week 10
desc: The first major phase of organ formation is nearing completion.
babyDevelopment: Toes, fingers, and eyelids develop; tooth buds appear; fetus about the size of a prune.
nutrition: Balanced meals with protein (beans, fish), calcium (milk, small fish), and folate continue to be important.

title: Week 11
desc: Risk of miscarriage falls for many; fetus continues growing quickly.
babyDevelopment: Bones begin to form and internal organs keep maturing; small movements begin.
nutrition: Keep iron and folate levels steady; include vitamin D through safe sun and diet if advised.

title: Week 12
desc: End of the first trimester for many — many symptoms ease and energy returns.
babyDevelopment: Fetus can open and close fingers; major organs are present and working.
nutrition: Increase fiber and water to combat constipation; continue prenatal vitamins and balanced meals.

title: Week 13
desc: Second trimester begins; nausea often improves and energy increases.
babyDevelopment: Fetus grows rapidly; neck lengthens and facial features refine.
nutrition: Add healthy fats and proteins — avocado, groundnuts (in moderation), and lean meats.

title: Week 14
desc: Fetal movements increase; mother may begin to feel subtle shifts in energy and appetite.
babyDevelopment: Fine hair (lanugo) forms; facial muscles allow small expressions.
nutrition: Continue balanced meals; include fruit for vitamins and fiber (bananas, oranges).

title: Week 15
desc: Bones continue to harden slightly and the fetus increases activity.
babyDevelopment: Skeleton begins to ossify (start of hardening); reflexes develop.
nutrition: Include vitamin D and calcium sources: milk, yogurt, small fish; sunlight exposure if safe.

title: Week 16
desc: Movements increase; some women begin to notice quickening later in pregnancy.
babyDevelopment: Sucking motions start; limbs lengthen and strengthen.
nutrition: Iron-rich snacks (beans, roasted groundnuts) and complex carbs (yam, plantain) to keep energy stable.

title: Week 17
desc: Fetal fat begins to form and the placenta continues maturing to support growth.
babyDevelopment: Fat accumulates beneath the skin and the circulatory system matures.
nutrition: Increase protein and healthy fats for baby’s development — fish low in mercury, eggs, legumes.

title: Week 18
desc: Hearing improves and the baby responds to external sounds.
babyDevelopment: Ears move to final positions and the baby may start to hear muffled sounds from outside.
nutrition: Continue iron and vitamin C (fruits) and include omega-3 sources for brain support.

title: Week 19
desc: Growth continues, movements become stronger and anatomy scans are common around this time.
babyDevelopment: Organs and tissues become more refined; baby practices breathing movements.
nutrition: Ensure adequate iron and calcium; consider snacks like boiled eggs and fruit to support energy.

title: Week 20
desc: Halfway point — baby’s movements are more noticeable; many have an anatomy scan this week.
babyDevelopment: Coordinated movement increases; organs continue maturing.
nutrition: Prioritize iron-rich meals and hydration; include vegetables and whole grains for steady energy.

title: Week 21
desc: Fetal activity rises and mothers often feel regular kicks and patterns.
babyDevelopment: Lanugo covers the baby and swallowing practice helps develop digestion.
nutrition: Maintain protein, fiber and hydration; include local staples like kontomire, beans, and plantain.

title: Week 22
desc: Sensory development continues; baby becomes more responsive to sounds and light.
babyDevelopment: Fingerprints and more distinct facial features develop; responds to voices.
nutrition: Vitamin C–rich fruits support iron uptake; include citrus, pawpaw and leafy greens.

title: Week 23
desc: The baby’s lungs and other organs continue maturing; movements feel stronger.
babyDevelopment: Lung tissues develop branching airways and fetal kicking increases.
nutrition: Balanced meals and snacks to meet growing calorie needs; whole grains and legumes are helpful.

title: Week 24
desc: Viability improves — babies born now have better chances with neonatal care.
babyDevelopment: Lungs produce surfactant and reflexes become stronger.
nutrition: Ensure iron, calcium and protein; monitor fetal movements and rest as needed.

title: Week 25
desc: Fat accumulation increases and movements become more forceful.
babyDevelopment: Fat stores under the skin increase and muscle tone improves.
nutrition: Include healthy fats, protein and fruits; try avocado, fish low in mercury, and legumes.

title: Week 26
desc: Lungs and nervous system mature quickly; baby’s eyes begin to open more.
babyDevelopment: Lungs practice breathing and the baby may open and close eyes.
nutrition: Keep calcium and vitamin D up; milk and fortified cereals help. Stay hydrated.

title: Week 27
desc: Third trimester begins; focus shifts to monitoring growth and comfort.
babyDevelopment: Baby sleeps and wakes in cycles, gains weight rapidly and responds to stimuli.
nutrition: Increase iron-rich meals and fiber to avoid constipation; include fruits and vegetables.

title: Week 28
desc: Rapid brain development occurs and the baby gains more fat for temperature regulation.
babyDevelopment: Neural development accelerates and body fat rises.
nutrition: Continue calcium and protein intake; small frequent meals ease heartburn.

title: Week 29
desc: Baby’s movements are strong and frequent; mothers should monitor patterns.
babyDevelopment: Muscle mass and coordination increase; bones continue maturing.
nutrition: Hydration and electrolyte balance are important; include soups and stews with vegetables.

title: Week 30
desc: Weight gain for mother and baby accelerates; prepare for birth discussions with your provider.
babyDevelopment: Fat increases and immune system strengthens; eyes react to light.
nutrition: Prioritize iron-rich lunches, calcium and protein; plan balanced meals with healthcare guidance.

title: Week 31
desc: Baby continues gaining weight and the position may shift toward head-down.
babyDevelopment: Nervous system matures and lungs develop more alveoli.
nutrition: Steady calories and protein are important; snack on fruits, nuts, and milk products.

title: Week 32
desc: Fetal lung and brain development continues; discuss birth preferences with your provider.
babyDevelopment: Baby practices breathing and swallowing; bones harden but remain flexible.
nutrition: Monitor iron and calcium intake; maintain fiber to avoid constipation.

title: Week 33
desc: Lungs mature rapidly and fat stores increase for temperature regulation after birth.
babyDevelopment: Hearing and other sensory systems sharpen; increased fat changes body shape.
nutrition: Eat nutrient-dense foods and stay hydrated; light activity as approved by your provider.

title: Week 34
desc: Baby readies for birth; many babies begin moving into a head-down position.
babyDevelopment: Digestive system matures and lungs continue to develop surfactant.
nutrition: Small frequent meals and fiber-rich foods to manage discomforts; prioritize calcium and iron.

title: Week 35
desc: Close to full term — finalize birth plans and pack hospital essentials.
babyDevelopment: Rapid weight gain continues; organs are nearly mature.
nutrition: Hydrate well and keep nutrient-dense snacks ready; focus on iron and protein.

title: Week 36
desc: Baby often drops lower into the pelvis; final organ maturation continues.
babyDevelopment: Lungs and brain finalize growth and baby settles toward the birth canal in many pregnancies.
nutrition: Keep balanced meals, frequent hydration and light, easily digestible foods before labor.

title: Week 37
desc: Full term begins; baby is generally ready for life outside the womb.
babyDevelopment: Organs are mature; baby continues to gain weight and regulate body systems.
nutrition: Rest, hydrate, and keep easy-to-eat nutrient-dense foods available for labor and recovery.

title: Week 38
desc: Final preparations continue; baby practices breathing and sucking.
babyDevelopment: Vernix and lanugo reduce; lungs, brain and digestive system prepare for birth.
nutrition: Small meals to avoid heartburn; maintain hydration and light proteins for energy.

title: Week 39
desc: Baby gains last layer of fat and is positioned for birth; labor could begin any time.
babyDevelopment: Lungs fully mature and baby’s body prepares for independent breathing and temperature regulation.
nutrition: Eat light balanced meals, hydrate, and follow your birth plan and provider’s guidance.

title: Week 40
desc: Your due date — many babies arrive around now, while others may come slightly earlier or later.
babyDevelopment: Baby is full term; organs are ready for life outside the womb.
nutrition: Stay hydrated, keep easy-to-digest meals available, and follow the healthcare team's instructions if labor begins.
